content: In the following questions, I will provide a target Python program code. The code is a program containing a loop, and the purpose of the code is indicated by its function name. def give_last(arr):
    last_value = arr[0]
    f = 0
    while f < len(arr):
        last_value = arr[f]
        f += 1
    return last_value

```less
last_value_i = arr[i]
```
This invariant ensures that the value of the last element in the array is maintained throughout the loop. It ensures that at each iteration, the value of `last_value` is updated with the value of the current element in the array, and ultimately, at the end of the loop, the value of `last_value` is what represents the last element of the array.

def give_last(arr):
    last_value = arr[0]
    f = 0
    while f <= len(arr) - 1:
        last_value = arr[f]
        f += 1
    return last_value

The loop invariant for the i-th iteration of the loop in the given program is:

* `last_value_i = arr[i]`

This invariant ensures that the value of the last element in the array is maintained throughout the loop. It ensures that at each iteration, the value of `last_value` is updated with the value of the current element in the array `arr[i]`.

When the loop iterates its last time, `f` will equal `len(arr) - 1` (as this is the condition of the loop). Since `f` is then used to access `arr[f]` and update `last_value`, this means that `last_value` will hold the last element of the array `arr`.

So, the loop invariant correctly states that `last_value` holds the last element of the array `arr` at each iteration of the loop.
